text:
The Cher is a river in central France. It is a left tributary of the Loire River. It flows through several regions of France.
The Cher and Loir-et-Cher departments are named after this river.
Geography.
The Cher is long. Its drainage basin covers.
Its average yearly discharge (volume of water which passes through a section of the river per unit of time) is at Tours, Indre-et-Loire (1966 - 2017), near its mouth.
Average monthly discharge (m3/s) at Tours
Course.
The Cher starts in the Massif Central, in the Mérinchal municipality, Creuse department, Nouvelle-Aquitaine region. It starts at an altitude of about.
At its end, the Cher flows into the Loire River at the "bec du Cher" ("beak of the Cher") in the Regional nature park Loire-Anjou-Touraine ("Parc naturel régional Loire-Anjou-Touraine") in Villandry. That is about west of the city of Tours, in the Indre-et-Loire department, at of altitude.
